review.title: Parameterized Complexity Results for Plan Reuse
review.abstract: Planning is a notoriously difficult computational problem of high worst-case complexity. Researchers have been investing significant efforts to develop heuristics or restrictions to make planning practically feasible. Case-based planning is a heuristic approach where one tries to reuse previous experience when solving similar problems in order to avoid some of the planning effort. Plan reuse may offer an interesting alternative to plan generation in some settings.
histories: Proceedings of AAAI 2013, pp. 224-231, AAAI Press, 2013
review.COMMENTS: Proceedings of AAAI 2013, pp. 224-231, AAAI Press, 2013

metadata.title: Parameterized Complexity Results for Plan Reuse

sections.text: ar Xiv: 130 7.44 40v1 [cs.AI] 16 JuWe provide theoretical results that identify situations where the reuse of a plan is demonstrably traceable. We perform our analysis within the framework of parameterized complexity, which supports a rigorous worst-case complexity analysis that takes into account the structural properties of the input in terms of parameters. A central concept of parameterized complexity is the traceability of defined parameters that extends the classical concept of polynomial time traceability by taking advantage of the effect of the structural properties of the input problem. We draw a detailed map of the parameterized complexity landscape of several problem variants that occur in the context of case-based planning. In particular, we consider the problem of the reuse of an existing plan that imposes various constraints on parameters, such as the number of steps that can be added to the existing plan in order to relate it to a solution of the present planning instance.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text: In fact, it is the case that one is able to put oneself at the top, and in the way in which one is able to put oneself at the top of society.

sections.heading: Preliminaries
sections.text: In this section, we present basic concepts and notations related to (case-based) planning and parameterized complexity that are further used in the publication. Planning In this study, we use the SAS + Planning Framework (Ba � ckstro � m and Nebbel 1996) in the notation variant of Chen and Gime ́ nez (2010): An instance of the planning problem or planning instance is a tuple (V, I, G, A) whose components are described as follows. • V is a finite instance of variables in which each v ² V has a related finite domain D (v). A state s is a mapping of variables defined in such a way that s (v) is a state that v ² A. A partial state p is a mapping defined on a subset of vars (p) of V.

sections.heading: Related Work
sections.text: The first paper, which presented a complexity theory study on the re-use of plans (Fog and Köhler 1995), looked at the so-called conservative re-use of plans. Conservative re-use of plans maximizes the unchanged part of the known solution. The authors showed that such re-use of plans is not demonstrably more efficient than the creation of plans. Furthermore, they show that the determination of the maximum re-usable part of the saved solution is an additional source of hardship. Liberatore (2005) examined the problem of re-use of plans in another way and interpreted the case (or the base case) as a "hint" that makes the search for the solution plan more informed. The complexity results he provided do not improve the complexity of the uninformed plan creation. However, it provides a comprehensible compilation of planning cases that differ from the stored instances only in a constant number of assessments that differ from the original state and goal.

sections.heading: Parameterized Complexity of Plan Reuse
sections.text: In this paper, we cannot rule out the parameterized complexity of the reuse of a plan and where a similar plan is needed. However, since this work is motivated by the reuse of a plan in the context of case-based planning, we use assumptions that are common in case-based approaches to ensure that there is a solution at hand that can be reused. We also consider a more specific form of plan reuse (case reuse) and generalizations that result from the fact that similar problems in their general form are no better than the classical complexity of plan reuse. Liberatore (2005) has shown that it will be PSPACE-complete. However, the case-based approach assumes that similar problems have similar solutions (Leake 1996), meaning that cases can either be used to achieve a solution by applying only a limited number of changes or will not be helpful in finding a solution.

sections.heading: Conclusion
sections.text: Within the framework of parameterized complexity, we provided theoretical results to identify situations where the re-use of a plan is demonstrably traceable. We drew a detailed map of the parameterized complexity landscape of several problem variants that occur in the context of case-based planning. Specifically, we considered the problem of re-use of an existing plan by imposing various parameter constraints, such as the number of steps that can be added to the existing plan in order to turn it into a solution for the planning instance. Results show that the fact that the number of modification measures is small does not guarantee traceability on its own. Furthermore, we must limit the number of measures that can be added to the modifications, indicating the need for a good heuristic function that identifies a limited number of measures that are used for modifications. In the future, these results may be expanded to include richer planning formalisms, e.g. by considering different types of prerequisites or using them in conjunction with specific expressions or variables.

referenceMentions.context: For instance, deciding whether there exists a plan for a given planning instance is PSPACE-complete, and the problem remains at least NP-hard under various restrictions (Bylander 1994).

To overcome this high worst-case complexity, various heuristics, restrictions, and relaxations of planning problems have been developed that work surprisingly well in practical settings (Hoffmann 2001; Helmert 2006).

To overcome this high worst-case complexity, various heuristics, restrictions, and relaxations of planning problems have been developed that work surprisingly well in practical settings (Hoffmann 2001; Helmert 2006).

Among the heuristic approaches is case-based planning, which proceeds from the idea that significant planning efforts may be saved by reusing previous solutions (Kambhampati and Hendler 1992; Veloso 1994).

Among the heuristic approaches is case-based planning, which proceeds from the idea that significant planning efforts may be saved by reusing previous solutions (Kambhampati and Hendler 1992; Veloso 1994).

For instance, deciding whether there exists a plan for a given planning instance is PSPACE-complete, and the problem remains at least NP-hard under various restrictions (Bylander 1994). To overcome this high worst-case complexity, various heuristics, restrictions, and relaxations of planning problems have been developed that work surprisingly well in practical settings (Hoffmann 2001; Helmert 2006). Among the heuristic approaches is case-based planning, which proceeds from the idea that significant planning efforts may be saved by reusing previous solutions (Kambhampati and Hendler 1992; Veloso 1994). This approach is based on the assumption that planning tasks tend to recur and that if the tasks are similar, then so are their solutions. Empirical evidence suggests that this assumption holds in many settings, and that the case-based approach works particularly well if the planning tasks require complex solutions while the modifications required on the known plans are considerably small. So far the research on the worst-case complexity of case-based planning did not take into account the essential assumption that similar planning tasks require similar solutions. Indeed, as shown by Liberatore (2005), if none of the known solutions are helpful, then the case-based system needs to invest an effort comparable to generating the solution from scratch, and hence does not benefit from the previous experience.

We perform our analysis in the framework of parameterized complexity, which supports a rigorous worst-case complexity analysis that takes structural properties of the input into account (Downey, Fellows, and Stege 1999; Niedermeier 2006; Gottlob and Szeider 2006).

LONGEST-COMMON-SUBSEQUENCE-I is a parameterized problem that is W[t]-hard for all t ≥ 1 (Bodlaender et al. 1995).
The first paper providing a complexity-theoretical study of plan reuse (Nebel and Koehler 1995) considered so-called conservative plan reuse.
Liberatore (2005) studied the problem of plan reuse in a different fashion, interpreting the case (or the case base) as a “hint” that makes the search for the solution plan more informed.

Liberatore (2005) studied the problem of plan reuse in a different fashion, interpreting the case (or the case base) as a “hint” that makes the search for the solution plan more informed. The complexity results he provides do not improve over the complexity of uninformed plan generation. He does however give a tractable compilation result for planning instances that differ from the stored instances only in a constant number of valuations from the initial state and goal. The parameterized complexity of planning was first studied by Downey, Fellows, and Stege (1999) and, more recently, by Bäckström et al.

More specifically, they provide a full classification of SAS+ planning under all combinations of the P, U, B and S restrictions introduced by Bäckström and Klein (1991), and they provide a full classification of STRIPS planning under the syntactical restrictions studied by Bylander (1994).

The result follows from the W[2]-completeness proof of finding a solution plan of at most k action occurrences (the k-step planning problem) given by Bäckström et al. (2012). They proved that W[2]-hardness already holds for complete goal states.
Similarly, we can require the set of actions A, from which glue steps can be taken, to be post-unique (Bäckström et al. 2012).

Bäckström et al. showed that for the k-step planning problem, complexity results can be improved by considering only planning instances whose actions satisfy the condition of post-uniqueness. Similarly, we can require the set of actions A, from which glue steps can be taken, to be post-unique (Bäckström et al. 2012). This parameterized problem is in fact fixed-parameter tractable (this result follows from Theorem 5 in Bäckström et al. (2012)).

The para-PSPACE-membership result follows from the fact that {D}-CASEMOD, when unparameterized, is in PSPACE (Bäckström and Nebel 1996). Since this hardness result holds already for a single value of k, the para-PSPACE-hardness result follows (Flum and Grohe 2003).
The claim follows directly from the proof of Proposition 1, since k-step planning is W[2]-complete already for Boolean planning instances (Bäckström et al. 2012).

The W[t]-membership results can then be proved by encoding the R-CASEMOD instances as instances of certain first-order model checking problems (Bäckström et al. 2012), and combining these into one model checking problem instance that is equivalent to the disjunction of the separate R-CASEMOD instances.
Since this parameterized halting problem is in W[P] (Cesati 2003), this suffices to show W[P]-membership.

metadata.abstractText: Planning is a notoriously difficult computational problem of high worst-case complexity. Researchers have been investing significant efforts to develop heuristics or restrictions to make planning practically feasible. Case-based planning is a heuristic approach where one tries to reuse previous experience when solving similar problems in order to avoid some of the planning effort. Plan reuse may offer an interesting alternative to plan generation in some settings. We provide theoretical results that identify situations in which plan reuse is provably tractable. We perform our analysis in the framework of parameterized complexity, which supports a rigorous worst-case complexity analysis that takes structural properties of the input into account in terms of parameters. A central notion of parameterized complexity is fixed-parameter tractability which extends the classical notion of polynomial-time tractability by utilizing the effect of structural properties of the problem input. We draw a detailed map of the parameterized complexity landscape of several variants of problems that arise in the context of case-based planning. In particular, we consider the problem of reusing an existing plan, imposing various restrictions in terms of parameters, such as the number of steps that can be added to the existing plan to turn it into a solution of the planning instance at hand.
